column5: Vesper takes her time and explores what the legendary Casino Royale has to offer to people who are fond of competitive programming.Her attention was grabbed by the very new ""Pull Your Luck"" roulette which functions in a pretty peculiar way. The roulette\'s wheel consists of n sectors number from 0 to n\xe2\x88\x921. There is no ball and the winning sector is determined by a static arrow pointing to one of the sectors. Sectors\' indexes go in the natural order and the wheel always spins in the direction of indexes increment. That means that sector i+1 goes right after sector i for all i from 0 to n\xe2\x88\x922
column6: and sector 0 goes right after sector n\xe2\x88\x921.After a bet is made
column7: the player is allowed to pull the triggering handle herself and cause the wheel to spin. If the player\'s initial pull is made with the force equal to positive integer f
column8: the wheel will spin for f seconds. During the first second it will advance f sectors
column9: the next second it will advance f\xe2\x88\x921 sectors
column10: then f\xe2\x88\x922 sectors
column11: and so on until it comes to a complete stop. After the wheel comes to a complete stop
column12: the sector which the arrow is pointing to is the winning one.The roulette\'s arrow currently points at sector x. Vesper knows that she can pull the handle with any integer force from 1 to p inclusive. Note that it is not allowed to pull the handle with force 0
column13: i.Â e. not pull it all. The biggest prize is awarded if the winning sector is 0. Now Vesper wonders if she can make sector 0 win by pulling the triggering handle exactly once?" 1500.0

column4: probabilities "Ela likes to go hiking a lot. She loves nature and exploring the various creatures it offers. One day
column5: she saw a strange type of ant
column6: with a cannibalistic feature. More specifically
column7: an ant would eat any ants that it sees which is smaller than it.Curious about this feature from a new creature
column8: Ela ain\'t furious. She conducts a long
column9: non-dubious
column10: sentimental experiment.She puts n cannibalistic ants in a line on a long wooden stick. Initially
column11: the ants have the same weight of 1. The distance between any two consecutive ants is the same. The distance between the first ant in the line to the left end and the last ant in the line to the right end is also the same as the distance between the ants. Each ant starts moving towards the left-end or the right-end randomly and equiprobably
column12: at the same constant pace throughout the experiment. Two ants will crash if they are standing next to each other in the line and moving in opposite directions
column13: and ants will change direction immediately when they reach the end of the stick. Ela can\'t determine the moving direction of each ant
column14: but she understands very well their behavior when crashes happen.  If a crash happens between two ants of different weights
column15: the heavier one will eat the lighter one
column16: and gain the weight of the lighter one. After that
column17: the heavier and will continue walking in the same direction. In other words
column18: if the heavier one has weight x and walking to the right
column19: the lighter one has weight y and walking to the left (x>y)
column20: then after the crash
column21: the lighter one will diminish
column22: and the heavier one will have weight x+y and continue walking to the right.  If a crash happens between two ants with the same weight
column23: the one walking to the left end of the stick will eat the one walking to the right
column24: and then continue walking in the same direction. In other words
column25: if one ant of weight x walking to the left
column26: crashes with another ant of weight x walking to the right
column27: the one walking to the right will disappear
column28: and the one walking to the left will have to weight 2x and continue walking to the left. Please
column29: check the example in the ""Note"" section
column30: which will demonstrate the ants\' behavior as above.We can prove that after a definite amount of time
column31: there will be only one last ant standing. Initially
column32: each ant can randomly and equiprobably move to the left or the right
column33: which generates 2n different cases of initial movements for the whole pack. For each position in the line
column34: calculate the probability that the ant begins in that position and survives. Output it modulo 109+7.Formally
column35: let M=109+7. It can be shown that the answer can be expressed as an irreducible fraction pq
column36: where p and q are integers and q\xe2\x89\xa20(modM). Output the integer equal to p\xe2\x8b\x85q\xe2\x88\x921modM. In other words
column37: output such an integer x that 0\xe2\x89\xa4x<M and x\xe2\x8b\x85q\xe2\x89\xa1p(modM)." 2500.0

column3: math" "There are n digital panels placed in a straight line. Each panel can show any digit from 0 to 9. Initially

column22: so it has the digit 0. The resulting 4-digit number is 1090. Note that this example is not optimal for n=4.Once all panels have been paused

column3: strings "After his wife\'s tragic death
column4: Eurydice
column5: Orpheus descended to the realm of death to see her. Reaching its gates was uneasy
column6: but passing through them proved to be even more challenging. Mostly because of Cerberus
column7: the three-headed hound of Hades. Orpheus
column8: a famous poet
column9: and musician plans to calm Cerberus with his poetry and safely walk past him. He created a very peculiar poem for Cerberus. It consists only of lowercase English letters. We call a poem\'s substring a palindrome if and only if it reads the same backwards and forwards. A string a is a substring of a string b if a can be obtained from b by deleting several (possibly zero or all) characters from the beginning and several (possibly zero or all) characters from the end.Unfortunately
column10: Cerberus dislikes palindromes of length greater than 1. For example in the poem abaa the hound of Hades wouldn\'t like substrings aba and aa.Orpheus can only calm Cerberus if the hound likes his poetry. That\'s why he wants to change his poem so that it does not contain any palindrome substrings of length greater than 1.Orpheus can modify the poem by replacing a letter at any position with any lowercase English letter. He can use this operation arbitrarily many times (possibly zero). Since there can be many palindromes in his poem
column11: he may have to make some corrections. But how many
column12: exactly? Given the poem
column13: determine the minimal number of letters that have to be changed so that the poem does not contain any palindromes of length greater than 1."

column5: trees" "This is an interactive problem.You are given a treeÂ \xe2\x80\x94 connected undirected graph without cycles. One vertex of the tree is special
column6: and you have to find which one. You can ask questions in the following form: given an edge of the tree
column7: which endpoint is closer to the special vertex
column8: meaning which endpoint\'s shortest path to the special vertex contains fewer edges. You have to find the special vertex by asking the minimum number of questions in the worst case for a given tree.Please note that the special vertex might not be fixed by the interactor in advance: it might change the vertex to any other one
column9: with the requirement of being consistent with the previously given answers."

column3: geometry" "One drew a closed polyline on a plane
column4: that consisted only of vertical and horizontal segments (parallel to the coordinate axes). The segments alternated between horizontal and vertical ones (a horizontal segment was always followed by a vertical one
column5: and vice versa). The polyline did not contain strict self-intersections

column8: the polyline was erased
column9: and you only know the lengths of the horizonal and vertical segments. Please construct any polyline matching the description with such segments
column10: or determine that it does not exist."

column3: fft "Today is the final contest of INOI (Iranian National Olympiad in Informatics). The contest room is a row with n computers. All computers are numbered with integers from 1 to n from left to right. There are m participants
column4: numbered with integers from 1 to m.We have an array a of length m where ai (1\xe2\x89\xa4ai\xe2\x89\xa4n) is the computer behind which the i-th participant wants to sit.Also
column5: we have another array b of length m consisting of characters \'L\' and \'R\'. bi is the side from which the i-th participant enters the room. \'L\' means the participant enters from the left of computer 1 and goes from left to right
column6: and \'R\' means the participant enters from the right of computer n and goes from right to left.The participants in the order from 1 to m enter the room one by one. The i-th of them enters the contest room in the direction bi and goes to sit behind the ai-th computer. If it is occupied he keeps walking in his direction until he reaches the first unoccupied computer. After that
column7: he sits behind it. If he doesn\'t find any computer he gets upset and gives up on the contest.The madness of the i-th participant is the distance between his assigned computer (ai) and the computer he ends up sitting behind. The distance between computers i and j is equal to |i\xe2\x88\x92j|.The values in the array a can be equal. There exist nm\xe2\x8b\x852m possible pairs of arrays (a
column8: b).Consider all pairs of arrays (a
column9: b) such that no person becomes upset. For each of them let\'s calculate the sum of participants madnesses. Find the sum of all these values.You will be given some prime modulo p. Find this sum by modulo p."

column6: sortings" "Chef Monocarp has just put n dishes into an oven. He knows that the i-th dish has its optimal cooking time equal to ti minutes.At any positive integer minute T Monocarp can put no more than one dish out of the oven. If the i-th dish is put out at some minute T
column7: then its unpleasant value is |T\xe2\x88\x92ti|Â \xe2\x80\x94 the absolute difference between T and ti. Once the dish is out of the oven
column8: it can\'t go back in.Monocarp should put all the dishes out of the oven. What is the minimum total unpleasant value Monocarp can obtain?"

column2: math" "Sasha likes investigating different math objects
column3: for example
column4: magic squares. But Sasha understands that magic squares have already been studied by hundreds of people
column5: so he sees no sense of studying them further. Instead
column6: he invented his own type of squareÂ \xe2\x80\x94 a prime square. A square of size n\xc3\x97n is called prime if the following three conditions are held simultaneously:   all numbers on the square are non-negative integers not exceeding 105;  there are no prime numbers in the square;  sums of integers in each row and each column are prime numbers. Sasha has an integer n. He asks you to find any prime square of size n\xc3\x97n. Sasha is absolutely sure such squares exist
column7: so just help him!"

column1: 800.0 1436A Reorder math "For a given array a consisting of n integers and a given integer m find if it is possible to reorder elements of the array a in such a way that \xe2\x88\x91ni=1\xe2\x88\x91nj=iajj equals m? It is forbidden to delete elements as well as insert new elements. Please note that no rounding occurs during division

2100.0 1433F "Zero Remainder Sum" dp "You are given a matrix a of size n\xc3\x97m consisting of integers.You can choose no more than \xe2\x8c\x8am2\xe2\x8c\x8b elements in each row. Your task is to choose these elements in such a way that their sum is divisible by k and this sum is the maximum.In other words
column2: you can choose no more than a half (rounded down) of elements in each row
column3: you have to find the maximum sum of these elements divisible by k.Note that you can choose zero elements (and the sum of such set is 0)."
greedy" "You want to train a neural network model for your graduation work. There are n images in the dataset

column5: so you decided to remove some images \xe2\x80\x94 though you don\'t want to make the dataset too weak so you can remove no more than k images from it. Note that you can only remove images
column6: you can\'t change their order.You want to remove these images optimally so you came up with a metric (you\'re a data scientist after all) that allows to measure the result of removals. Consider the array b1

column19: and it\'s okay.Let w(i) be the total size of the i-th block \xe2\x80\x94 that is

column23: the value of the metric is cntmaxi=1w(i).You don\'t want to overload your machine too much
column24: so you have to remove at most k images in a way that minimizes the value of the metric described above."

column1: 2000.0 1431E "Chess Match" "*special problem" "The final of Berland Chess Team Championship is going to be held soon. Two teams consisting of n chess players each will compete for first place in the tournament. The skill of the i-th player in the first team is ai
column2: and the skill of the i-th player in the second team is bi. The match will be held as follows: each player of the first team will play a game against one player from the second team in such a way that every player has exactly one opponent. Formally
column3: if the player i from the first team opposes the player pi from the second team
column4: then [p1
column5: p2
column6: \xe2\x80\xa6
column7: pn] is a permutation (a sequence where each integer from 1 to n appears exactly once).Whenever two players of almost equal skill play a game
column8: it will likely result in a tie. Chess fans don\'t like ties
column9: so the organizers of the match should distribute the players in such a way that ties are unlikely.Let the unfairness of the match be the following value: nmini=1|ai\xe2\x88\x92bpi|. Your task is to assign each player from the first team an opponent from the second team so that the unfairness is maximum possible (the greater it is
column10: the smaller the probability of ties is
column11: that\'s why you should maximize it)."

column1: 1400.0 1431B "Polycarp and the Language of Gods" "*special problem
column3: two pointers" "Polycarp has just finished writing down the lecture on elvish languages. The language this week was ""VwV"" (pronounced as ""uwu""). The writing system of this language consists of only two lowercase Latin letters: \'v\' and \'w\'.Unfortunately
column4: Polycarp has written all the lecture in cursive and without any spaces
column5: so the notes look like a neverending sequence of squiggles. To be exact
column6: Polycarp can\'t tell \'w\' apart from \'vv\' in his notes as both of them consist of the same two squiggles.Luckily
column7: his brother Monocarp has better writing habits
column8: so Polycarp managed to take his notes and now wants to make his own notes more readable. To do that he can follow the notes of Monocarp and underline some letters in his own notes in such a way that there is no more ambiguity. If he underlines a \'v\'
column9: then it can\'t be mistaken for a part of some \'w\'
column10: and if the underlines a \'w\'
column11: then it can\'t be mistaken for two adjacent letters \'v\'.What is the minimum number of letters Polycarp should underline to make his notes unambiguous?"

column3: strings" "You are given a string s. You have to reverse it \xe2\x80\x94 that is
column4: the first letter should become equal to the last letter before the reversal
column5: the second letter should become equal to the second-to-last letter before the reversal \xe2\x80\x94 and so on. For example
column6: if your goal is to reverse the string ""abddea""
column7: you should get the string ""aeddba"". To accomplish your goal
column8: you can swap the neighboring elements of the string. Your task is to calculate the minimum number of swaps you have to perform to reverse the given string."

column3: math" "Recently a new building with a new layout was constructed in Monocarp\'s hometown. According to this new layout
column4: the building consists of three types of apartments: three-room
column5: five-room
column6: and seven-room apartments. It\'s also known that each room of each apartment has exactly one window. In other words
column7: a three-room apartment has three windows
column8: a five-roomÂ \xe2\x80\x94 five windows
column9: and a seven-roomÂ \xe2\x80\x94 seven windows.Monocarp went around the building and counted n windows. Now he is wondering
column10: how many apartments of each type the building may have.Unfortunately
column11: Monocarp only recently has learned to count
column12: so he is asking you to help him to calculate the possible quantities of three-room
column13: five-room
column14: and seven-room apartments in the building that has n windows. If there are multiple answers
column15: you can print any of them.Here are some examples:  if Monocarp has counted 30 windows
column16: there could have been 2 three-room apartments
column17: 2 five-room apartments and 2 seven-room apartments
column18: since 2\xe2\x8b\x853+2\xe2\x8b\x855+2\xe2\x8b\x857=30;  if Monocarp has counted 67 windows
column19: there could have been 7 three-room apartments
column20: 5 five-room apartments and 3 seven-room apartments
column21: since 7\xe2\x8b\x853+5\xe2\x8b\x855+3\xe2\x8b\x857=67;  if Monocarp has counted 4 windows
column22: he should have mistaken since no building with the aforementioned layout can have 4 windows."

column7: math" "Alice and Bob have decided to play the game ""Rock
column8: Paper
column9: Scissors"". The game consists of several rounds
column10: each round is independent of each other. In each round
column11: both players show one of the following things at the same time: rock
column12: paper or scissors. If both players showed the same things then the round outcome is a draw. Otherwise
column13: the following rules applied:  if one player showed rock and the other one showed scissors
column14: then the player who showed rock is considered the winner and the other one is considered the loser;  if one player showed scissors and the other one showed paper
column15: then the player who showed scissors is considered the winner and the other one is considered the loser;  if one player showed paper and the other one showed rock
column16: then the player who showed paper is considered the winner and the other one is considered the loser. Alice and Bob decided to play exactly n rounds of the game described above. Alice decided to show rock a1 times
column17: show scissors a2 times and show paper a3 times. Bob decided to show rock b1 times
column18: show scissors b2 times and show paper b3 times. Though
column19: both Alice and Bob did not choose the sequence in which they show things. It is guaranteed that a1+a2+a3=n and b1+b2+b3=n.Your task is to find two numbers:  the minimum number of round Alice can win;  the maximum number of rounds Alice can win."

column1: 900.0 1426B "Symmetric Matrix" implementation "Masha has n types of tiles of size 2\xc3\x972. Each cell of the tile contains one integer. Masha has an infinite number of tiles of each type.Masha decides to construct the square of size m\xc3\x97m consisting of the given tiles. This square also has to be a symmetric with respect to the main diagonal matrix
column2: and each cell of this square has to be covered with exactly one tile cell
column3: and also sides of tiles should be parallel to the sides of the square. All placed tiles cannot intersect with each other. Also
column4: each tile should lie inside the square. See the picture in Notes section for better understanding.Symmetric with respect to the main diagonal matrix is such a square s that for each pair (i
column5: j) the condition s[i][j]=s[j][i] holds. I.e. it is true that the element written in the i-row and j-th column equals to the element written in the j-th row and i-th column.Your task is to determine if Masha can construct a square of size m\xc3\x97m which is a symmetric matrix and consists of tiles she has. Masha can use any number of tiles of each type she has to construct the square. Note that she can not rotate tiles
column6: she can only place them in the orientation they have in the input.You have to answer t independent test cases."

column4: 0).  The third box stores toys with fun values in range of (0
column5: 1).  The fourth box stores toys with fun value in range of [1
column6: \xe2\x88\x9e). Chaneka has A
column7: B
column8: C
column9: D toys in the first
column10: second
column11: third
column12: and fourth box
column13: respectively. One day she decides that she only wants one toy
column14: a super toy. So she begins to create this super toy by sewing all the toys she has.While the number of toys Chaneka has is more than 1
column15: she takes two different toys randomly and then sews them together
column16: creating a new toy. The fun value of this new toy is equal to the multiplication of fun values of the sewn toys. She then puts this new toy in the appropriate box. She repeats this process until she only has one toy. This last toy is the super toy
column17: and the box that stores this toy is the special box.As an observer
column18: you only know the number of toys in each box initially but do not know their fun values. You also don\'t see the sequence of Chaneka\'s sewing. Determine which boxes can be the special box after Chaneka found her super toy."

column1: 1400.0 1425F "Flamingoes of Mystery" interactive "This is an interactive problem. You have to use a flush operation right after printing each line. For example
column2: in C++ you should use the function fflush(stdout)
column3: in Java \xe2\x80\x94 System.out.flush()
column4: in Pascal \xe2\x80\x94 flush(output) and in Python \xe2\x80\x94 sys.stdout.flush().Mr. Chanek wants to buy a flamingo to accompany his chickens on his farm. Before going to the pet shop
column5: Mr. Chanek stops at an animal festival to have fun. It turns out there is a carnival game with a flamingo as the prize.There are N mysterious cages
column6: which are numbered from 1 to N. Cage i has Ai (0\xe2\x89\xa4Ai\xe2\x89\xa4103) flamingoes inside (1\xe2\x89\xa4i\xe2\x89\xa4N). However
column7: the game master keeps the number of flamingoes inside a secret. To win the flamingo
column8: Mr. Chanek must guess the number of flamingoes in each cage.Coincidentally
column9: Mr. Chanek has N coins. Each coin can be used to ask once
column10: what is the total number of flamingoes inside cages numbered L to R inclusive? With L<R."

column2: sortings" "During one of the space missions
column3: humans have found an evidence of previous life at one of the planets. They were lucky enough to find a book with birth and death years of each individual that had been living at this planet. What\'s interesting is that these years are in the range (1
column4: 109)! Therefore
column5: the planet was named Longlifer.In order to learn more about Longlifer\'s previous population
column6: scientists need to determine the year with maximum number of individuals that were alive
column7: as well as the number of alive individuals in that year. Your task is to help scientists solve this problem!"

column1: 3000.0 1423I "Lookup Tables" bitmasks "John has Q closed intervals of consecutive 2K-bit numbers [li
column2: ri] and one 16-bit value vi for each interval. (0\xe2\x89\xa4i<Q)John wants to implement a function F that maps 2K-bit numbers to 16-bit numbers in such a way that inputs from each interval are mapped to that interval\'s value. In other words: F(x)=vi
column3: for everyÂ 0\xe2\x89\xa4i<Q
column4: and everyÂ x\xe2\x88\x88[li
column5: ri] The output of F for other inputs is unimportant.John wants to make his implementation of F fast so he has decided to use lookup tables. A single 2K-bit lookup table would be too large to fit in memory
column6: so instead John plans to use two K-bit lookup tables
column7: LSBTable and MSBTable. His implementation will look like this: F(x)=LSBTable[lowKBits(x)]&MSBTable[highKBits(x)] In other words it returns the ""bitwise and"" of results of looking up the K least significant bits in LSBTable and the K most significant bits in MSBTable.John needs your help. Given K
column8: Q and Q intervals [li
column9: ri] and values vi
column10: find any two lookup tables which can implement F or report that such tables don\'t exist."

column1: 3500.0 1423G "Growing flowers" "data structures" "Sarah has always been a lover of nature
column2: and a couple of years ago she saved up enough money to travel the world and explore all the things built by nature over its lifetime on earth. During this time she visited some truly special places which were left untouched for centuries
column3: from watching icebergs in freezing weather to scuba-diving in oceans and admiring the sea life
column4: residing unseen. These experiences were enhanced with breathtaking views built by mountains over time and left there for visitors to see for years on end. Over time
column5: all these expeditions took a toll on Sarah and culminated in her decision to settle down in the suburbs and live a quiet life. However
column6: as Sarah\'s love for nature never faded
column7: she started growing flowers in her garden in an attempt to stay connected with nature. At the beginning she planted only blue orchids
column8: but over time she started using different flower types to add variety to her collection of flowers. This collection of flowers can be represented as an array of N flowers and the i-th of them has a type associated with it
column9: denoted as Ai. Each resident
column10: passing by her collection and limited by the width of his view
column11: can only see K contiguous flowers at each moment in time. To see the whole collection
column12: the resident will look at the first K contiguous flowers A1
column13: A2
column15: AK
column16: then shift his view by one flower and look at the next section of K contiguous flowers A2
column17: A3
column19: AK+1 and so on until they scan the whole collection
column20: ending with section AN\xe2\x88\x92K+1
column22: AN\xe2\x88\x921
column23: AN.Each resident determines the beautiness of a section of K flowers as the number of distinct flower types in that section. Furthermore
column24: the beautiness of the whole collection is calculated by summing the beautiness values of each contiguous section. Formally
column25: beautiness Bi of a section starting at the i-th position is calculated as Bi=distinct(Ai
column26: Ai+1
column29: and beautiness of the collection B is calculated as B=B1+B2+...+BN\xe2\x88\x92K+1.In addition
column30: as Sarah wants to keep her collection of flowers have a fresh feel
column31: she can also pick two points L and R
column32: dispose flowers between those two points and plant new flowers
column33: all of them being the same type.You will be given Q queries and each of those queries will be of the following two types:   You will be given three integers L
column35: X describing that Sarah has planted flowers of type X between positions L and R inclusive. Formally collection is changed such that A[i]=X for all i in range [L..R].  You will be given integer K
column36: width of the resident\'s view and you have to determine the beautiness value B resident has associated with the collection For each query of second type print the result \xe2\x80\x93 beautiness B of the collection."

column3: trees" "As you may already know
column4: Du\xc5\xa1an is keen on playing with railway models. He has a big map with cities that are connected with railways. His map can be seen as a graph where vertices are cities and the railways connecting them are the edges. So far
column5: the graph corresponding to his map is a tree. As you already know
column6: a tree is a connected acyclic undirected graph.He is curious to find out whether his railway can be optimized somehow. He wants to add so-called shortcuts
column7: which are also railways connecting pairs of cities. This shortcut will represent the railways in the unique path in the tree between the pair of cities it connects. Since Du\xc5\xa1an doesn\'t like repeating the railways
column8: he has also defined good paths in his newly obtained network (notice that after adding the shortcuts
column9: his graph is no more a tree). He calls a path good
column10: if no edge appears more than once
column11: either as a regular railway edge or as an edge represented by some shortcut (Every shortcut in a good path has length 1
column12: but uses up all the edges it represents - they can\'t appear again in that path). Having defined good paths
column13: he defines good distance between two cities to be the length of the shortest good path between them. Finally
column14: the shortcutting diameter of his network is the largest good distance between any two cities.Now he is curious to find out whether it is possible to achieve shortcutting diameter less or equal than k
column15: while adding as few shortcuts as possible.Your solution should add no more than 10\xe2\x8b\x85n shortcuts."

column3: math "Sometimes it is not easy to come to an agreement in a bargain. Right now Sasha and Vova can\'t come to an agreement: Sasha names a price as high as possible
column4: then Vova wants to remove as many digits from the price as possible. In more details
column5: Sasha names some integer price n
column6: Vova removes a non-empty substring of (consecutive) digits from the price
column7: the remaining digits close the gap
column8: and the resulting integer is the price.For example
column9: is Sasha names 1213121
column10: Vova can remove the substring 1312
column11: and the result is 121.It is allowed for result to contain leading zeros. If Vova removes all digits
column12: the price is considered to be 0.Sasha wants to come up with some constraints so that Vova can\'t just remove all digits
column13: but he needs some arguments supporting the constraints. To start with
column14: he wants to compute the sum of all possible resulting prices after Vova\'s move.Help Sasha to compute this sum. Since the answer can be very large
column15: print it modulo 109+7."

column3: sortings" "Ori and Sein have overcome many difficult challenges. They finally lit the Shrouded Lantern and found Gumon Seal
column4: the key to the Forlorn Ruins. When they tried to open the door to the ruins... nothing happened.Ori was very surprised
column5: but Sein gave the explanation quickly: clever Gumon decided to make an additional defence for the door.There are n lamps with Spirit Tree\'s light. Sein knows the time of turning on and off for the i-th lampÂ \xe2\x80\x94 li and ri respectively. To open the door you have to choose k lamps in such a way that there will be a moment of time when they all will be turned on.While Sein decides which of the k lamps to pick
column6: Ori is interested: how many ways there are to pick such k lamps that the door will open? It may happen that Sein may be wrong and there are no such k lamps. The answer might be large
column7: so print it modulo 998244353."

column3: you\'re boxes with legs! It is literally your only purpose! Walking onto buttons! How can you not do the one thing you were designed for?Oh
column4: that\'s funny

column2: strings "Shubham has a binary string s. A binary string is a string containing only characters ""0"" and ""1"".He can perform the following operation on the string any amount of times:   Select an index of the string

column12: zero or all) characters."

column12: one of them can send a signal directly to the other one. Otherwise

column14: and then the central sends it to the second base. We denote the distance between two bases as the total Euclidean distance that a signal sent between them has to travel.Bond can damage all but some k bases
column15: which he can choose arbitrarily. A damaged base can\'t send or receive the direct signal but still can pass it between two working bases. In particular

column18: so the distance between them remains the same. What is the maximal sum of the distances between all pairs of remaining bases that 007 can achieve by damaging exactly n\xe2\x88\x92k of them?"

column3: if the qubits passed to your operation are in the state 1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|11\xe2\x9f\xa9+|10\xe2\x9f\xa9)=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|3\xe2\x9f\xa9+|1\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column4: they should be transformed to the state 1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|(3+1)mod22\xe2\x9f\xa9+|(1+1)mod22\xe2\x9f\xa9)=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|0\xe2\x9f\xa9+|2\xe2\x9f\xa9)=1\xe2\x88\x9a2(|00\xe2\x9f\xa9+|01\xe2\x9f\xa9).Your code should have the following signature (note that your operation should have Adjoint and Controlled variants defined for it; is Adj+Ctl in the operation signature will generate them automatically based on your code):namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Arithmetic;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Intrinsic;    operation Solve (register : LittleEndian) : Unit is Adj+Ctl {        // your code here    }}Your code is not allowed to use measurements or arbitrary rotation gates (so
column5: for example
column6: using the library operation IncrementByInteger will cause runtime error). This operation can be implemented using just the X gate and its controlled variants."

column12: that unlike the numbers multiplication

column1: -999.0                         1116D1 "Block diagonal matrix"  "Implement a unitary operation on N qubits which is represented by a square matrix of size 2N which has 2x2 blocks of non-zero elements on the main diagonal and zero elements everywhere else.For example
column2: for N=3 the matrix of the operation should have the following shape:XX......XX........XX......XX........XX......XX........XX......XXHere X denotes a ""non-zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value greater than or equal to 10\xe2\x88\x925)
column3: and . denotes a ""zero"" element of the matrix (a complex number which has the square of the absolute value less than 10\xe2\x88\x925).The row and column indices of the matrix follow little endian format: the least significant bit of the index is stored first in the qubit array. Thus
column4: the first column of the matrix gives you the coefficients of the basis states you\'ll get if you apply the unitary to the |00..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state
column5: the second column - to the |10..0\xe2\x9f\xa9 basis state etc. You can use the DumpUnitary tool to get the coefficients of the matrix your unitary implements (up to relative phases between columns) and the corresponding pattern of Xs and .s.You have to implement an operation which takes an array of N (2\xe2\x89\xa4N\xe2\x89\xa45) qubits as an input and applies the unitary transformation with the matrix of the described shape to it. If there are multiple unitaries which satisfy the requirements
column6: you can implement any of them. The ""output"" of your operation is the pattern of the matrix coefficients implemented by it; you can see the testing harness in the UnitaryPatterns kata.Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;    operation Solve (qs : Qubit[]) : Unit {        // your code here    }}You are not allowed to use measurements in your operation."

column1: -999.0                         1116B1 "Distinguish three-qubit states"  "You are given 3 qubits which are guaranteed to be in one of the two states: |\xcf\x880\xe2\x9f\xa9=1\xe2\x88\x9a3(|100\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x89|010\xe2\x9f\xa9+\xcf\x892|001\xe2\x9f\xa9)
column3: where \xcf\x89=e2i\xcf\x80/3.Your task is to perform necessary operations and measurements to figure out which state it was and to return 0 if it was |\xcf\x880\xe2\x9f\xa9 state or 1 if it was |\xcf\x881\xe2\x9f\xa9 state. The state of the qubits after the operations does not matter.You have to implement an operation which takes an array of 3 qubits as an input and returns an integer. Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {    open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;    open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;    operation Solve (qs : Qubit[]) : Int {        // your code here    }}"

column3: strings" "Reading books is one of Sasha\'s passions. Once while he was reading one book
column4: he became acquainted with an unusual character. The character told about himself like that: ""Many are my names in many countries. Mithrandir among the Elves
column5: Thark\xc3\xbbn to the Dwarves
column6: Ol\xc3\xb3rin I was in my youth in the West that is forgotten
column7: in the South Inc\xc3\xa1nus
column8: in the North Gandalf; to the East I go not.""And at that moment Sasha thought
column9: how would that character be called in the East? In the East all names are palindromes. A string is a palindrome if it reads the same backward as forward. For example
column10: such strings as ""kazak""
column11: ""oo"" and ""r"" are palindromes
column12: but strings ""abb"" and ""ij"" are not. Sasha believed that the hero would be named after one of the gods of the East. As long as there couldn\'t be two equal names
column13: so in the East people did the following: they wrote the original name as a string on a piece of paper
column14: then cut the paper minimum number of times k
column15: so they got k+1 pieces of paper with substrings of the initial string
column16: and then unite those pieces together to get a new string. Pieces couldn\'t be turned over
column17: they could be shuffled.In this way
column18: it\'s possible to achive a string abcdefg from the string f|de|abc|g using 3 cuts (by swapping papers with substrings f and abc). The string cbadefg can\'t be received using the same cuts.More formally
column19: Sasha wants for the given palindrome s find such minimum k
column20: that you can cut this string into k+1 parts
column21: and then unite them in such a way that the final string will be a palindrome and it won\'t be equal to the initial string s. It there is no answer
column22: then print ""Impossible"" (without quotes)."

column9: but still comes to the floor from the x-th floor).  Moves from the b-th floor back to the x-th.  The elevator never transposes more than one person and always goes back to the floor x before transposing a next passenger. The elevator spends one unit of electricity to move between neighboring floors. So moving from the a-th floor to the b-th floor requires |a\xe2\x88\x92b| units of electricity.Your task is to help Nut to find the minimum number of electricity units
column10: that it would be enough for one day
column11: by choosing an optimal the x-th floor. Don\'t forget than elevator initially stays on the x-th floor."

column2: greedy" "BerkomnadzorÂ \xe2\x80\x94 Federal Service for Supervision of Communications
column3: Information Technology and Mass MediaÂ \xe2\x80\x94 is a Berland federal executive body that protects ordinary residents of Berland from the threats of modern internet.Berkomnadzor maintains a list of prohibited IPv4 subnets (blacklist) and a list of allowed IPv4 subnets (whitelist). All Internet Service Providers (ISPs) in Berland must configure the network equipment to block access to all IPv4 addresses matching the blacklist. Also ISPs must provide access (that is
column4: do not block) to all IPv4 addresses matching the whitelist. If an IPv4 address does not match either of those lists
column5: it\'s up to the ISP to decide whether to block it or not. An IPv4 address matches the blacklist (whitelist) if and only if it matches some subnet from the blacklist (whitelist). An IPv4 address can belong to a whitelist and to a blacklist at the same time
column6: this situation leads to a contradiction (see no solution case in the output description).An IPv4 address is a 32-bit unsigned integer written in the form a.b.c.d
column7: where each of the values a
column8: b
column9: c
column10: d is called an octet and is an integer from 0 to 255 written in decimal notation. For example
column11: IPv4 address 192.168.0.1 can be converted to a 32-bit number using the following expression 192\xe2\x8b\x85224+168\xe2\x8b\x85216+0\xe2\x8b\x8528+1\xe2\x8b\x8520. First octet a encodes the most significant (leftmost) 8 bits
column12: the octets b and cÂ \xe2\x80\x94 the following blocks of 8 bits (in this order)
column13: and the octet d encodes the least significant (rightmost) 8 bits.The IPv4 network in Berland is slightly different from the rest of the world. There are no reserved or internal addresses in Berland and use all 232 possible values.An IPv4 subnet is represented either as a.b.c.d or as a.b.c.d/x (where 0\xe2\x89\xa4x\xe2\x89\xa432). A subnet a.b.c.d contains a single address a.b.c.d. A subnet a.b.c.d/x contains all IPv4 addresses with x leftmost (most significant) bits equal to x leftmost bits of the address a.b.c.d. It is required that 32\xe2\x88\x92x rightmost (least significant) bits of subnet a.b.c.d/x are zeroes.Naturally it happens that all addresses matching subnet a.b.c.d/x form a continuous range. The range starts with address a.b.c.d (its rightmost 32\xe2\x88\x92x bits are zeroes). The range ends with address which x leftmost bits equal to x leftmost bits of address a.b.c.d
column14: and its 32\xe2\x88\x92x rightmost bits are all ones. Subnet contains exactly 232\xe2\x88\x92x addresses. Subnet a.b.c.d/32 contains exactly one address and can also be represented by just a.b.c.d.For example subnet 192.168.0.0/24 contains range of 256 addresses. 192.168.0.0 is the first address of the range
column15: and 192.168.0.255 is the last one.Berkomnadzor\'s engineers have devised a plan to improve performance of Berland\'s global network. Instead of maintaining both whitelist and blacklist they want to build only a single optimised blacklist containing minimal number of subnets. The idea is to block all IPv4 addresses matching the optimised blacklist and allow all the rest addresses. Of course
column16: IPv4 addresses from the old blacklist must remain blocked and all IPv4 addresses from the old whitelist must still be allowed. Those IPv4 addresses which matched neither the old blacklist nor the old whitelist may be either blocked or allowed regardless of their accessibility before. Please write a program which takes blacklist and whitelist as input and produces optimised blacklist. The optimised blacklist must contain the minimal possible number of subnets and satisfy all IPv4 addresses accessibility requirements mentioned above. IPv4 subnets in the source lists may intersect arbitrarily. Please output a single number -1 if some IPv4 address matches both source whitelist and blacklist."

column1: 1200.0                         1032B "Personalized Cup"  "At many competitions that have a word \xc2\xabcup\xc2\xbb in its official name the winner is presented with an actual cup. This time the organizers of one unusual programming competition have decided to please the winner even more and to add a nameplate to the cup with the handle of the winner.The nameplate is to be rectangular and the text on it will be printed as a table of several rows and columns. Having some measurements done
column2: the organizers have found out that the number a of rows cannot be greater than 5 while the number b of columns cannot exceed 20. Every cell of the table will contain either an asterisk (\xc2\xab*\xc2\xbb) or a letter of user\'s handle.Furthermore
column3: the organizers want the rows of the table to be uniform
column4: which means that the number of asterisks used in different rows should differ by at most one (i.e. you can\'t have two asterisks in the first row and none in the second). The main goal
column5: however
column6: is to obtain the winner\'s handle precisely when reading the table from top to bottom and from left to right in every row (skipping asterisks).The organizers want for the nameplate to have as few rows as possible and among all valid tables with the minimum number of rows they want to choose the one that has the minimum number of columns.The winner is not yet determined so your task is to write a program that
column7: given a certain handle
column8: generates the necessary table."

column3: math "You received a notebook which is called Death Note. This notebook has infinite number of pages. A rule is written on the last page (huh) of this notebook. It says: ""You have to write names in this notebook during n consecutive days. During the i-th day you have to write exactly ai names."". You got scared (of course you got scared
column4: who wouldn\'t get scared if he just receive a notebook which is named Death Note with a some strange rule written in it?).Of course
column5: you decided to follow this rule. When you calmed down
column6: you came up with a strategy how you will write names in the notebook. You have calculated that each page of the notebook can contain exactly m names. You will start writing names from the first page. You will write names on the current page as long as the limit on the number of names on this page is not exceeded. When the current page is over
column7: you turn the page. Note that you always turn the page when it ends
column8: it doesn\'t matter if it is the last day or not. If after some day the current page still can hold at least one name
column9: during the next day you will continue writing the names from the current page.Now you are interested in the following question: how many times will you turn the page during each day? You are interested in the number of pages you will turn each day from 1 to n."

column3: probabilities "Leha is planning his journey from Moscow to Saratov. He hates trains
column4: so he has decided to get from one city to another by car.The path from Moscow to Saratov can be represented as a straight line (well
column5: it\'s not that straight in reality
column6: but in this problem we will consider it to be straight)
column7: and the distance between Moscow and Saratov is n km. Let\'s say that Moscow is situated at the point with coordinate 0 km
column8: and Saratov \xe2\x80\x94 at coordinate n km.Driving for a long time may be really difficult. Formally
column9: if Leha has already covered i kilometers since he stopped to have a rest
column10: he considers the difficulty of covering (i+1)-th kilometer as ai+1. It is guaranteed that for every i\xe2\x88\x88[1
column11: n\xe2\x88\x921] ai\xe2\x89\xa4ai+1. The difficulty of the journey is denoted as the sum of difficulties of each kilometer in the journey.Fortunately
column12: there may be some rest sites between Moscow and Saratov. Every integer point from 1 to n\xe2\x88\x921 may contain a rest site. When Leha enters a rest site
column13: he may have a rest
column14: and the next kilometer will have difficulty a1
column15: the kilometer after it \xe2\x80\x94 difficulty a2
column16: and so on.For example
column17: if n=5 and there is a rest site in coordinate 2
column18: the difficulty of journey will be 2a1+2a2+a3: the first kilometer will have difficulty a1
column19: the second one \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column20: then Leha will have a rest
column21: and the third kilometer will have difficulty a1
column22: the fourth \xe2\x80\x94 a2
column23: and the last one \xe2\x80\x94 a3. Another example: if n=7 and there are rest sites in coordinates 1 and 5
column24: the difficulty of Leha\'s journey is 3a1+2a2+a3+a4.Leha doesn\'t know which integer points contain rest sites. So he has to consider every possible situation. Obviously
column25: there are 2n\xe2\x88\x921 different distributions of rest sites (two distributions are different if there exists some point x such that it contains a rest site in exactly one of these distributions). Leha considers all these distributions to be equiprobable. He wants to calculate p \xe2\x80\x94 the expected value of difficulty of his journey.Obviously
column26: p\xe2\x8b\x852n\xe2\x88\x921 is an integer number. You have to calculate it modulo 998244353."

column2: math "You might have heard about the next game in Lara Croft series coming out this year. You also might have watched its trailer. Though you definitely missed the main idea about its plot
column3: so let me lift the veil of secrecy.Lara is going to explore yet another dangerous dungeon. Game designers decided to use good old 2D environment. The dungeon can be represented as a rectangle matrix of n rows and m columns. Cell (x

column3: string suffix structures" "You are given a string s consisting of n lowercase Latin letters.Let\'s denote k-substring of s as a string subsk\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89sksk\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891..sn\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89k. Obviously

column2: trees" "Santa has an infinite number of candies for each of m flavours. You are given a rooted tree with n vertices. The root of the tree is the vertex 1. Each vertex contains exactly one candy. The i-th vertex has a candy of flavour fi.Sometimes Santa fears that candies of flavour k have melted. He chooses any vertex x randomly and sends the subtree of x to the Bakers for a replacement. In a replacement
column3: all the candies with flavour k are replaced with a new candy of the same flavour. The candies which are not of flavour k are left unchanged. After the replacement
column4: the tree is restored.The actual cost of replacing one candy of flavour k is ck (given for each k). The Baker keeps the price fixed in order to make calculation simple. Every time when a subtree comes for a replacement
column5: the Baker charges C
column6: no matter which subtree it is and which flavour it is.Suppose that for a given flavour k the probability that Santa chooses a vertex for replacement is same for all the vertices. You need to find out the expected value of error in calculating the cost of replacement of flavour k. The error in calculating the cost is defined as follows.ErrorÂ E(k)=Â (ActualCostÂ \xe2\x80\x93Â PriceÂ chargedÂ byÂ theÂ Bakers)2.Note that the actual cost is the cost of replacement of one candy of the flavour k multiplied by the number of candies in the subtree.Also
column7: sometimes Santa may wish to replace a candy at vertex x with a candy of some flavour from his pocket.You need to handle two types of operations:   Change the flavour of the candy at vertex x to w.  Calculate the expected value of error in calculating the cost of replacement for a given flavour k."

column3: graphs" "You are given a directed graph with n nodes and m edges
column4: with all edges having a certain weight. There might be multiple edges and self loops
column5: and the graph can also be disconnected. You need to choose a path (possibly passing through same vertices multiple times) in the graph such that the weights of the edges are in strictly increasing order
column6: and these edges come in the order of input. Among all such paths
column7: you need to find the the path that has the maximum possible number of edges
column8: and report this value.Please note that the edges picked don\'t have to be consecutive in the input."

column3: trees" "You have a full binary tree having infinite levels.Each node has an initial value. If a node has value x
column4: then its left child has value 2\xc2\xb7x and its right child has value 2\xc2\xb7x\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891. The value of the root is 1. You need to answer Q queries. There are 3 types of queries:  Cyclically shift the values of all nodes on the same level as node with value X by K units. (The values/nodes of any other level are not affected). Cyclically shift the nodes on the same level as node with value X by K units. (The subtrees of these nodes will move along with them). Print the value of every node encountered on the simple path from the node with value X to the root.Positive K implies right cyclic shift and negative K implies left cyclic shift. It is guaranteed that atleast one type 3 query is present."

column1: 2600.0                         958F3 "Lightsabers (hard)" fft "There used to be unrest in the Galactic Senate. Several thousand solar systems had declared their intentions to leave the Republic. But fear not! Master Heidi was able to successfully select the Jedi Knights that have restored peace in the galaxy. However
column2: she knows that evil never sleeps and a time may come when she will need to pick another group of Jedi Knights. She wants to be sure she has enough options to do so.There are n Jedi Knights
column3: each of them with a lightsaber of one of m colors. Given a number k
column4: compute the number of differently colored collections of k lightsabers that some k Jedi Knights might have. Jedi Knights with lightsabers of the same color are indistinguishable (it\'s not the person
column5: it\'s the lightsaber color that matters!)
column6: and their order does not matter; that is
column7: we consider two collections of Jedi Knights to be different if and only if their vectors of counts of lightsabers of each color (like what you were given in the easy and the medium versions) are different. We count all subsets
column8: not only contiguous subsegments of the input sequence. Output the answer modulo 1009."

column8: spies may have accidentally rotated a map by 90
column10: or 270 degrees
column11: or flipped it along the vertical or the horizontal axis
column12: before delivering it to Heidi. If Heidi can rotate or flip the maps so that two of them become identical
column13: then those maps are of the same solar system. Otherwise
column14: there are traitors in the Rebel ranks! Help Heidi find out."

column2: dp" "Arkady wants to have a dinner. He has just returned from a shop where he has bought a semifinished cutlet. He only needs to fry it. The cutlet should be fried for 2n seconds

column12: find the minimum number of flips he needs to cook the cutlet."

Values s and f are equal for all time zones. If the contest starts at f hours 00 minutes local time
column8: the person won\'t participate in it.Help platform select such an hour
column9: that the number of people who will participate in the contest is maximum."

column2: implementation" "Fafa owns a company that works on huge projects. There are n employees in Fafa\'s company. Whenever the company has a new project to start working on

column5: Fafa will divide the tasks among only the team leaders and each team leader will be responsible of some positive number of employees to give them the tasks. To make this process fair for the team leaders
column6: each one of them should be responsible for the same number of employees. Moreover
column7: every employee
column8: who is not a team leader

column10: and no team leader is responsible for another team leader.Given the number of employees n
column11: find in how many ways Fafa could choose the number of team leaders l in such a way that it is possible to divide employees between them evenly."

column1: 800.0                         932A "Palindromic Supersequence" "constructive algorithms" "You are given a string A. Find a string B
column2: where B is a palindrome and A is a subsequence of B.A subsequence of a string is a string that can be derived from it by deleting some (not necessarily consecutive) characters without changing the order of the remaining characters. For example
column3: ""cotst"" is a subsequence of ""contest"".A palindrome is a string that reads the same forward or backward.The length of string B should be at most 104. It is guaranteed that there always exists such string.You do not need to find the shortest answer
column4: the only restriction is that the length of string B should not exceed 104."

column6: which belongs to each segment. However Teodor is lazy person and neither wills to tell Sasha all coordinates of segments\' ends nor wills to tell him their amount

column8: how many segments in Fedya\'s picture contain that point?\'
column9: promising to tell correct answers for this questions.Both boys are very busy studying and don\'t have much time
column10: so they ask you to find out how many questions can Sasha ask Teodor
column11: that having only answers on his questions
column12: Sasha can\'t be sure that Teodor isn\'t lying to him. Note that Sasha doesn\'t know amount of segments in Teodor\'s picture. Sure
column13: Sasha is smart person and never asks about same point twice."

column2: sortings "Of course our child likes walking in a zoo. The zoo has n areas
column3: that are numbered from 1 to n. The i-th area contains ai animals in it. Also there are m roads in the zoo

column5: so you can reach any area of the zoo from any other area using the roads.Our child is very smart. Imagine the child want to go from area p to area q. Firstly he considers all the simple routes from p to q. For each route the child writes down the number
column6: that is equal to the minimum number of animals among the route areas. Let\'s denote the largest of the written numbers as f(p
column7: \xe2\x80\x89q). Finally
column8: the child chooses one of the routes for which he writes down the value f(p
column9: \xe2\x80\x89q).After the child has visited the zoo
column10: he thinks about the question: what is the average value of f(p
column11: \xe2\x80\x89q) for all pairs p
column12: \xe2\x80\x89q (p\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa0\xe2\x80\x89q)? Can you answer his question?" 1900.0

column1: 436D "Pudding Monsters" dp "Have you ever played Pudding Monsters? In this task
column2: a simplified one-dimensional model of this game is used.  Imagine an infinite checkered stripe
column3: the cells of which are numbered sequentially with integers. Some cells of the strip have monsters
column4: other cells of the strip are empty. All monsters are made of pudding
column5: so if there are two monsters in the neighboring cells
column6: they stick to each other (literally). Similarly
column7: if several monsters are on consecutive cells
column8: they all stick together in one block of monsters. We will call the stuck together monsters a block of monsters. A detached monster
column9: not stuck to anyone else
column10: is also considered a block.In one move
column11: the player can take any block of monsters and with a movement of his hand throw it to the left or to the right. The selected monsters will slide on until they hit some other monster (or a block of monsters).For example
column12: if a strip has three monsters in cells 1
column13: 4 and 5
column14: then there are only four possible moves: to send a monster in cell 1 to minus infinity
column15: send the block of monsters in cells 4 and 5 to plus infinity
column16: throw monster 1 to the right (it will stop in cell 3)
column17: throw a block of monsters in cells 4 and 5 to the left (they will stop in cells 2 and 3).Some cells on the strip are marked with stars. These are the special cells. The goal of the game is to make the largest possible number of special cells have monsters on them.You are given the numbers of the special cells on a strip as well as the initial position of all monsters. What is the maximum number of special cells that will contain monsters in the optimal game?" 2800.0

An empty cell is denoted as ""."" on the map
column5: but if a cell has a candy
column6: it is denoted as a letter of the English alphabet. A level may contain identical candies
column7: in this case the letters in the corresponding cells of the map will be the same.  When you transmit information via a network
column8: you want to minimize traffic \xe2\x80\x94 the total size of the transferred data. The levels can be transmitted in any order. There are two ways to transmit the current level A:  You can transmit the whole level A. Then you need to transmit n\xc2\xb7m bytes via the network.  You can transmit the difference between level A and some previously transmitted level B (if it exists); this operation requires to transmit dA
column9: \xe2\x80\x89B\xc2\xb7w bytes
column10: where dA
column11: \xe2\x80\x89B is the number of cells of the field that are different for A and B
column12: and w is a constant. Note
column13: that you should compare only the corresponding cells of levels A and B to calculate dA
column14: \xe2\x80\x89B. You cannot transform the maps of levels
column15: i.e. rotate or shift them relatively to each other. Your task is to find a way to transfer all the k levels and minimize the traffic." 1800.0

column2: implementation" "Many students live in a dormitory. A dormitory is a whole new world of funny amusements and possibilities but it does have its drawbacks. There is only one shower and there are multiple students who wish to have a shower in the morning. That\'s why every morning there is a line of five people in front of the dormitory shower door. As soon as the shower opens
column3: the first person from the line enters the shower. After a while the first person leaves the shower and the next person enters the shower. The process continues until everybody in the line has a shower.Having a shower takes some time
column4: so the students in the line talk as they wait. At each moment of time the students talk in pairs: the (2i\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x891)-th man in the line (for the current moment) talks with the (2i)-th one. Let\'s look at this process in more detail. Let\'s number the people from 1 to 5. Let\'s assume that the line initially looks as 23154 (person number 2 stands at the beginning of the line). Then
column5: before the shower opens
column6: 2 talks with 3
column7: 1 talks with 5
column8: 4 doesn\'t talk with anyone. Then 2 enters the shower. While 2 has a shower
column9: 3 and 1 talk
column10: 5 and 4 talk too. Then
column11: 3 enters the shower. While 3 has a shower
column12: 1 and 5 talk
column13: 4 doesn\'t talk to anyone. Then 1 enters the shower and while he is there
column14: 5 and 4 talk. Then 5 enters the shower
column15: and then 4 enters the shower.We know that if students i and j talk
column16: then the i-th student\'s happiness increases by gij and the j-th student\'s happiness increases by gji. Your task is to find such initial order of students in the line that the total happiness of all students will be maximum in the end. Please note that some pair of students may have a talk several times. In the example above students 1 and 5 talk while they wait for the shower to open and while 3 has a shower." 1200.0

column3: math "Polycarpus develops an interesting theory about the interrelation of arithmetic progressions with just everything in the world. His current idea is that the population of the capital of Berland changes over time like an arithmetic progression. Well
column4: or like multiple arithmetic progressions.Polycarpus believes that if he writes out the population of the capital for several consecutive years in the sequence a1
column7: \xe2\x80\x89an
column8: then it is convenient to consider the array as several arithmetic progressions
column9: written one after the other. For example
column10: sequence (8
column18: \xe2\x80\x892) can be considered as a sequence of three arithmetic progressions (8
column26: which are written one after another.Unfortunately
column27: Polycarpus may not have all the data for the n consecutive years (a census of the population doesn\'t occur every year
column28: after all). For this reason
column29: some values of ai \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8bmay be unknown. Such values are represented by number -1.For a given sequence a\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x89(a1
column32: \xe2\x80\x89an)
column33: which consists of positive integers and values \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b-1
column34: find the minimum number of arithmetic progressions Polycarpus needs to get a. To get a
column35: the progressions need to be written down one after the other. Values \xe2\x80\x8b\xe2\x80\x8b-1 may correspond to an arbitrary positive integer and the values ai\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x890 must be equal to the corresponding elements of sought consecutive record of the progressions.Let us remind you that a finite sequence c is called an arithmetic progression if the difference ci\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891\xe2\x80\x89-\xe2\x80\x89ci of any two consecutive elements in it is constant. By definition
column36: any sequence of length 1 is an arithmetic progression." 2400.0

Is it true that y is larger than or equal to number x?  Is it true that y is smaller than or equal to number x? On each question the host answers truthfully
column6: ""yes"" or ""no"".Given the sequence of questions and answers

column2: divide and conquer" "The last product of the R2 company in the 2D games\' field is a new revolutionary algorithm of searching for the shortest path in a 2\xe2\x80\x89\xc3\x97\xe2\x80\x89n maze.Imagine a maze that looks like a 2\xe2\x80\x89\xc3\x97\xe2\x80\x89n rectangle

column8: as the chief R2 programmer

column1: 412D "Giving Awards" "dfs and similar" "The employees of the R1 company often spend time together: they watch football

column6: and then immediately invite person y

column2: strings "Developers often face with regular expression patterns. A pattern is usually defined as a string consisting of characters and metacharacters that sets the rules for your search. These patterns are most often used to check whether a particular string meets the certain rules.In this task
column3: a pattern will be a string consisting of small English letters and question marks (\'?\'). The question mark in the pattern is a metacharacter that denotes an arbitrary small letter of the English alphabet. We will assume that a string matches the pattern if we can transform the string into the pattern by replacing the question marks by the appropriate characters. For example
column4: string aba matches patterns: ???
column6: a?a
column7: aba.Programmers that work for the R1 company love puzzling each other (and themselves) with riddles. One of them is as follows: you are given n patterns of the same length
column8: you need to find a pattern that contains as few question marks as possible
column9: and intersects with each of the given patterns. Two patterns intersect if there is a string that matches both the first and the second pattern. Can you solve this riddle?" 1200.0

column2: implementation "The R1 company has recently bought a high rise building in the centre of Moscow for its main office. It\'s time to decorate the new office

column4: so the decorators hung a large banner
column5: n meters wide and 1 meter high
column6: divided into n equal squares. The first character of the slogan must be in the first square (the leftmost) of the poster
column7: the second character must be in the second square
column8: and so on.Of course
column9: the R1 programmers want to write the slogan on the poster themselves. To do this
column10: they have a large (and a very heavy) ladder which was put exactly opposite the k-th square of the poster. To draw the i-th character of the slogan on the poster
column11: you need to climb the ladder
column12: standing in front of the i-th square of the poster. This action (along with climbing up and down the ladder) takes one hour for a painter. The painter is not allowed to draw characters in the adjacent squares when the ladder is in front of the i-th square because the uncomfortable position of the ladder may make the characters untidy. Besides
column13: the programmers can move the ladder. In one hour
column14: they can move the ladder either a meter to the right or a meter to the left.Drawing characters and moving the ladder is very tiring
column15: so the programmers want to finish the job in as little time as possible. Develop for them an optimal poster painting plan!" 900.0

column1: 411B "Multi-core Processor" implementation "The research center Q has developed a new multi-core processor. The processor consists of n cores and has k cells of cache memory. Consider the work of this processor.At each cycle each core of the processor gets one instruction: either do nothing
column2: or the number of the memory cell (the core will write an information to the cell). After receiving the command
column3: the core executes it immediately. Sometimes it happens that at one cycle
column4: multiple cores try to write the information into a single cell. Unfortunately
column5: the developers did not foresee the possibility of resolving conflicts between cores
column6: so in this case there is a deadlock: all these cores and the corresponding memory cell are locked forever. Each of the locked cores ignores all further commands
column7: and no core in the future will be able to record an information into the locked cell. If any of the cores tries to write an information into some locked cell
column8: it is immediately locked.The development team wants to explore the deadlock situation. Therefore
column9: they need a program that will simulate the processor for a given set of instructions for each core within m cycles . You\'re lucky
column10: this interesting work is entrusted to you. According to the instructions
column11: during the m cycles define for each core the number of the cycle
column12: during which it will become locked. It is believed that initially all cores and all memory cells are not locked." 1600.0

column1: 392A "Blocked Points" math "Imagine you have an infinite 2D plane with Cartesian coordinate system. Some of the integral points are blocked

column3: such that A is 4-connected with C

column1: 391F3 "Stock Trading"  "This problem consists of three subproblems: for solving subproblem F1 you will receive 8 points
column2: for solving subproblem F2 you will receive 15 points
column3: and for solving subproblem F3 you will receive 10 points.Manao has developed a model to predict the stock price of a company over the next n days and wants to design a profit-maximizing trading algorithm to make use of these predictions. Unfortunately
column4: Manao\'s trading account has the following restrictions:   It only allows owning either zero or one shares of stock at a time;  It only allows buying or selling a share of this stock once per day;  It allows a maximum of k buy orders over the next n days; For the purposes of this problem
column5: we define a trade to a be the act of buying one share of stock on day i
column6: then holding the stock until some day j\xe2\x80\x89>\xe2\x80\x89i at which point the share is sold. To restate the above constraints
column7: Manao is permitted to make at most k non-overlapping trades during the course of an n-day trading period for which Manao\'s model has predictions about the stock price.Even though these restrictions limit the amount of profit Manao can make compared to what would be achievable with an unlimited number of trades or the ability to hold more than one share at a time
column8: Manao still has the potential to make a lot of money because Manao\'s model perfectly predicts the daily price of the stock. For example
column9: using this model
column10: Manao could wait until the price is low
column11: then buy one share and hold until the price reaches a high value
column12: then sell for a profit
column13: and repeat this process up to k times until n days have passed.Nevertheless
column14: Manao is not satisfied by having a merely good trading algorithm
column15: and wants to develop an optimal strategy for trading subject to these constraints. Help Manao achieve this goal by writing a program that will determine when to buy and sell stock to achieve the greatest possible profit during the n-day trading period subject to the above constraints." -999.0

column5: sortings" "In the evenings Donkey would join Shrek to look at the stars. They would sit on a log
column6: sipping tea and they would watch the starry sky. The sky hung above the roof
column7: right behind the chimney. Shrek\'s stars were to the right of the chimney and the Donkey\'s stars were to the left. Most days the Donkey would just count the stars
column8: so he knew that they are exactly n. This time he wanted a challenge. He imagined a coordinate system: he put the origin of the coordinates at the intersection of the roof and the chimney
column9: directed the OX axis to the left along the roof and the OY axis \xe2\x80\x94 up along the chimney (see figure). The Donkey imagined two rays emanating from he origin of axes at angles \xce\xb11 and \xce\xb12 to the OX axis.  Now he chooses any star that lies strictly between these rays. After that he imagines more rays that emanate from this star at the same angles \xce\xb11 and \xce\xb12 to the OX axis and chooses another star that lies strictly between the new rays. He repeats the operation as long as there still are stars he can choose between the rays that emanate from a star.   As a result
column10: the Donkey gets a chain of stars. He can consecutively get to each star if he acts by the given rules.Your task is to find the maximum number of stars m that the Donkey\'s chain can contain.Note that the chain must necessarily start in the point of the origin of the axes
column11: that isn\'t taken into consideration while counting the number m of stars in the chain." 2700.0

column1: 227B "Effective Approach" implementation "Once at a team training Vasya
column2: Petya and Sasha got a problem on implementing linear search in an array.According to the boys
column3: linear search works as follows. The array elements in a pre-selected order are in turn compared with the number that you need to find. Once you find the array element that is equal to the required one
column4: the search ends. The efficiency of the algorithm is the number of performed comparisons. The fewer comparisons the linear search has made
column5: the more effective it is.Vasya believes that a linear search would work better if it sequentially iterates through the elements
column6: starting with the 1-st one (in this problem we consider the elements of the array indexed from 1 to n) and ending with the n-th one. And Petya says that Vasya is wrong: the search will need less comparisons if it sequentially iterates the elements starting from the n-th and ending with the 1-st one. Sasha argues that the two approaches are equivalent.To finally begin the task
column7: the teammates decided to settle the debate and compare the two approaches on an example. For this
column8: they took an array that is a permutation of integers from 1 to n
column9: and generated m queries of the form: find element with value bi in the array. They want to calculate for both approaches how many comparisons in total the linear search will need to respond to all queries. If the first search needs fewer comparisons
column10: then the winner of the dispute is Vasya. If the second one does
column11: then the winner is Petya. If both approaches make the same number of comparisons
column12: then Sasha\'s got the upper hand.But the problem is
column13: linear search is too slow. That\'s why the boys aren\'t going to find out who is right before the end of the training
column14: unless you come in here. Help them to determine who will win the dispute." 1100.0

column6: the leader of the space forces of Bit-X.There are n stations around Bit-X numbered clockwise from 1 to n. The stations are evenly placed on a circular orbit
column7: so the stations number i and i\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x891 (1\xe2\x80\x89\xe2\x89\xa4\xe2\x80\x89i\xe2\x80\x89<\xe2\x80\x89n)

column11: covering a distance of at least one space mile
column12: before finishing in some (perhaps the starting) station.Bitonix\' rocket moves by burning fuel tanks. After Bitonix attaches an x-liter fuel tank and chooses the direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise)
column13: the rocket flies exactly x space miles along a circular orbit in the chosen direction. Note that the rocket has no brakes; it is not possible for the rocket to stop before depleting a fuel tank.For example
column14: assume that n\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x893 and m\xe2\x80\x89=\xe2\x80\x8960 and Bitonix has fuel tanks with volumes of 10
column16: 90 and 100 liters. If Bitonix starts from station 1
column17: uses the 100-liter fuel tank to go clockwise
column18: then uses the 90-liter fuel tank to go clockwise
column19: and then uses the 10-liter fuel tank to go counterclockwise
column20: he will finish back at station 1. This constitutes a valid patrol. Note that Bitonix does not have to use all available fuel tanks. Another valid option for Bitonix in this example would be to simply use the 60-liter fuel tank to fly to either station 2 or 3.However
column21: if n was equal to 3
column22: m was equal to 60 and the only fuel tanks available to Bitonix were one 10-liter tank and one 100-liter tank
column23: he would have no way of completing a valid patrol (he wouldn\'t be able to finish any patrol exactly at the station).The Byteland space agency wants to destroy some of Captain Bitonix\' fuel tanks so that he cannot to complete any valid patrol. Find how many different subsets of the tanks the agency can destroy to prevent Captain Bitonix from completing a patrol and output the answer modulo 1000000007 (109\xe2\x80\x89+\xe2\x80\x897)." 2900.0

column1: 216C "Hiring Staff" greedy "A new Berland businessman Vitaly is going to open a household appliances\' store. All he\'s got to do now is to hire the staff.The store will work seven days a week
column2: but not around the clock. Every day at least k people must work in the store.Berland has a law that determines the order of working days and non-working days. Namely
column3: each employee must work for exactly n consecutive days
column4: then rest for exactly m days
column5: then work for n more days and rest for m more
column6: and so on. Vitaly doesn\'t want to break the law. Fortunately
column7: there is a loophole: the law comes into force on the day when the employee is hired. For example
column8: if an employee is hired on day x
column9: then he should work on days [x
column17: and so on. Day x can be chosen arbitrarily by Vitaly.There is one more thing: the key to the store. Berland law prohibits making copies of keys
column18: so there is only one key. Vitaly is planning to entrust the key to the store employees. At the same time on each day the key must be with an employee who works that day \xe2\x80\x94 otherwise on this day no one can get inside the store. During the day the key holder can give the key to another employee
column19: if he also works that day. The key will handed to the first hired employee at his first working day.Each employee has to be paid salary. Therefore
column20: Vitaly wants to hire as few employees as possible provided that the store can operate normally on each day from 1 to infinity. In other words
column21: on each day with index from 1 to infinity
column22: the store must have at least k working employees
column23: and one of the working employees should have the key to the store.Help Vitaly and determine the minimum required number of employees
column24: as well as days on which they should be hired." 1800.0
